thread.title: Senators push adminstration on currency manipulation
thread.title_full: Senators push adminstration on currency manipulation

author: bgoad@thehill.com (Vicki Needham)
title: Senators push adminstration on currency manipulation
text: Senators push adminstration on currency manipulation Thinkstock By Vicki Needham - 07/16/15 12:04 PM EDT A bipartisan group of senators on Thursday urged the Obama administration to crack down on global currency manipulation they argue hurts U.S. exporters. Led by Ohio Sens. Sherrod Brown (D) and Rob Portman (R), eight Senate Finance Committee members wrote a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman and Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew, calling on them to push for stronger enforcement provisions in ongoing negotiations of a massive Asia-Pacific trade deal. “As you continue negotiations on the Trans-Pacific Partnership, we urge you to prioritize combatting currency manipulation by our competitors,” they wrote. Portman and Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-Mich.) failed to get stronger currency manipulation language into trade promotion authority legislation, or fast-track, that was signed last month month by President Obama. That legislation included negotiating objectives that explicitly call on the White House to tackle currency manipulation through the ongoing trade negotiations. “American workers can compete and win in the global economy if given a level playing field,” they wrote. "Currency manipulation is one of the most egregious efforts undertaken to harm the competitiveness of hard-working manufacturers, farmers and small businesses throughout the U.S.," they wrote. The letter also was signed by Sens. Michael Bennet (D-Colo.), Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.), Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and Richard Burr (R-N.C.), all members of the Senate Finance Committee.
